Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2013 01:18PM franky wrote: Anyone have problems healing in any area?  I am 4 weeks post surgery - lumpectomy with octoplasty.  Tumor was at 6 o'clock so doc cut the slice out of my lower left breast where the tumor was, cut underneath the breast and pulled the two sides back together (like a reduction).  When they do that they also cut around the areola and move that whole part up so it is in the center again (otherwise would be on the lower part of the breast - not awesome).  I have/had D cup breasts and my lumpectomy still left a C+ on the left.  The incision part on the underneath of the breast closest to the rib cage still will not scab over.  This is where much of the draining was taking place and now it just stays warmer and a little moist sometimes based on the weight of the breast resting on it. I am squirting the open sore with hydrogen peroxide 2x/day to try to dry it out and still in no real bra alternating between tight camis, sports bras and a couple of surgical bras they gave me.  The opening is getting smaller but very slowly.  I want it to heal ASAP before I start chemo on 7/23.  Anyone else have this issue?  Tips to make it heal faster?
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy: Your tips for preparation & recovery? CassDugan carol57

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2013 12:26PM franky wrote: TxAgSueB - I wanted to comment on your question about Vitamin D.  I am always low in Vitamin D everytime I get tested even though I take Vitamin D supplements.  Even when I lived in a sunny southern city and ran outside all summer long I tested very low in Vitamin D.  Now I live in Seattle and my treatment center (Seattle Cancer Care Alliance) had done alot of research on the cause of breast cancer.  The PacNW has a higher incident rate than the rest of the country so they are really focused on determining why that is the case.  Of course, in my mind Seattle gave me cancer since I didn't have it before I lived here and there is such a high rate here.  They don't have any firm evidence at this point but are looking at the high rate of Vitamin D deficiency in the area due to the lack of sun. Has anyone ever heard of anything that helps with Vitamin D absorbtion?  Maybe take the Vitamin D supplement with another vitamin that helps with absorbtion?  I am not sure if this is one of the main reasons I developed breast cancer but I am definitely going to try to solve this to keep my Vitamin D levels up the rest of my life.  I am only 43 and have alot of years to go. Stay strong, ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2013 Mellie289 JeriGrace

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2013 01:46PM franky wrote: First time reading these message boards and first post on it.  I think my diagnosis details will appear below in my signature but just in case.....stage 1, 2cm, grade 3, triple negative.....diagnosis on 5/10, lumpectomy on 6/13, chemo starting week of 7/22, radiation after chemo (trifecta!) Onco rec TC regimen with the option for AC/T if I preferred.  She feels like the long term risks of AC/T do not outweigh the benefits of the heavier treatment in my case.  I think this might be the way the universe is trying to make me 'happy' about my chemo.  I was really feeling like I wasn't sure I could do the AC/T (4 x AC every 2 week and 12 x T weekly) and my onco thru me a curve ball by recommending TC (only 4 x every 3 weeks).  Less time, fewer sessions, no port (!). Here we go....buckle up, I think this might be a bumpy ride!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2013 Mellie289 JeriGrace
